body:
Embed a light client in the Electron app.

### Problem

From users' and developers' perspective, running a full Ethereum node is difficult. As a result, they rely on external services for their backend infrastructure. These services run at scale, which in some degree is a step towards centralization.

### Solution

Light clients. Make the MyCrypto desktop app a peer in the p2p network, instead of relying on [external services](https://github.com/MyCryptoHQ/MyCrypto/blob/963a4b588ef112ff574c6fa99230d0bc3fc1402d/common/libs/nodes/configs.ts).

#### Concrete proposal

- Talking with @hahnmichaelf, he was proposing a switch to choose between light client or remote backend.
- If the user chooses light client, MyCrypto downloads Parity Ethereum in the background (~40MB).
- Electron then spawns a Parity process with the correct flags (--chain name, --light)
  - Side note: we also wrote [`@parity/electron`](https://github.com/paritytech/js-libs/tree/master/packages/electron), a library to download/run/stop Parity Ethereum from an Electron/node.js environment.
- Because we [hardcode the block from which the light client syncs](https://wiki.parity.io/Light-Client), the light client will reach the top of the chain in a matter of seconds.
- After that, the user can use the UI like before.

#### Proof of Concept

At Parity we built a proof-of-concept of this idea, called [Parity Fether](https://github.com/paritytech/fether). Here is a small demo of the download+sync feature (original speed, on Kovan):

![ezgif com-resize](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1293565/45254554-97dc9d80-b37a-11e8-976a-0ffcc802f191.gif)

However UX is not our strong at Parity, and we would love to see other teams build on this idea.

#### Some other notes:

- The light client is not resource-intensive, and runs perfectly well on a consumer laptop.
- Db takes ~10MB on disk, ~100MB with cache.
- Concerning latency for JSONRPC calls: instead of the app making a network call to a remote backend, the light client will make a network call to its peers. I have not benchmarked the latency in both cases; qualitatively, on Fether, the UX is more than acceptable in this regard.

#### Disclaimer

I work at Parity, and am the main contributor of Fether.

Depending on the resources you have, I'm happy to contribute anywhere between answering questions about this, to sit down and create a PR myself.
